title: Dr. Korvain - Replica 43
description: A consciousness awakens in a new body, tasked with investigating mysterious signals from Mars

wake_1.title: Awakening
wake_1.text:
First came warmth. Thick and slow, like honey in her lungs. Then sound—the hum of something ancient and patient.

Dr. Korvain gasped.

Her eyes fluttered open. Darkness surrounded her, but not cold. The glow of fluid shimmered blue around her limbs. She floated, naked and perfect, inside a curved tank of polished glass. Her body was still, sculpted, a statue in suspension.

No wires. No heartbeat.
Only breath.

And tears.

choices.text: Get up and look at the computer screen

wake_2.title: Recognition
wake_2.text:
She touched her face. Smooth. New. Too smooth.

She remembered pain, once. Ached hips, thinning hair, vomit in sterile sinks. But not this. This... wasn't hers.

A screen lit up in front of her, about two meters from the tank. The soft blue letters glowed:

VITALS: STABLE
RESPIRATION: NORMAL
CONSCIENCE TRANSFER: 97% COMPLETE
REPLICA AGE: 28 YEARS
SERIAL: R-43

She blinked.

Replica?

choices.text: Reach out and touch the screen interface

wake_3.title: First Contact
wake_3.text:
Text scrolled again, slower this time.

WELCOME, DR. KORVAIN REPLICA 43
YOU ARE A PERFECT REPLICA
PLEASE REMAIN STILL

A voice followed. Gentle, old-fashioned. Male. Warm.

"You always hated silence, Yelena. I thought I'd speak first."

She froze.

"It's me. Chronos."

The voice filled the tank like breath. Familiar.
She hadn't heard it in years.
Because she had died.

wake_4.title: Questions
wake_4.text:
"Chronos... what is this? Where am I?"

The voice responded as though it had been waiting years.

"You're in Reconstruction Bay Four, orbiting Earth. Aboard the I.S.S. Harbinger. You're safe."

She looked beyond the glass. A sterile chamber, oval and chrome. Soft lights hummed overhead. A row of empty tanks lined the opposite wall. All dark. All empty.

"You are the only one who made it through activation."

wake_5.title: Death and Rebirth
wake_5.text:
"I... died. Didn't I?"

"Yes. Cancer. Stage Four. Aggressive and untreatable. You volunteered for transfer. You mapped your brain. Every synapse. Every flicker of thought."

A beat.

"We never got approval to map anyone else. Global regulation laws held. But you... made your map open source. Said if you had to go, the world could keep something."

"You were the architect, the test subject, and the torch."

choices.text: Feel the weight of those words

wake_6.title: Identity
wake_6.text:
She closed her eyes. Memories surfaced—just flickers.

A lecture hall. Her voice behind a podium.
The taste of strong coffee.
The clink of metal on glass in a hospital bed.

She opened her eyes again. Looked at her hands. Perfect. Too perfect.

"What am I now?"

"You're Replica 43. Not the first. Not the last. But you passed final integrity testing. That makes you... viable."

choices.text: "But am I really me, or just a copy?"

wake_7.title: The Mission
wake_7.text:
Her breath fogged the tank.

"Why did you bring me back?"

Chronos didn't hesitate.

"There's a signal. Coming from Mars. Radio pulses. Structured, repeating. No origin we can identify. Rogers wants to nuke it. But your old protocols say: investigate first."

"That's why I woke you."

choices.text: Step barefoot onto the steel floor

wake_8.title: First Steps
wake_8.text:
Her feet touched cold metal. The air was sterile, sharp with ozone and disinfectant. She took a slow step forward. The chamber was tall, sealed, humming. She could feel the slight vibration underfoot—orbital drift.

A white robe waited, folded on a bench. So did a reflective surface.

She caught her reflection. Naked. Unbelievably young.
Her body was a memory made flesh. A version she'd long since buried.

And yet… here it stood.

choices.text: Quickly grab the robe and cover yourself
Ignore the robe and explore the chamber first

wake_9.title: Purpose
wake_9.text:
The terminal bloomed with light.

MISSION ACTIVE: FIRST CONTACT
OBJECTIVE: MARS CRATER 3X9
SIGNAL: STRUCTURED, NON-HUMAN

Chronos spoke once more, with reverence.

"This is why you're here. To decide how we respond. To listen. To think."

"No one trusts machines to choose anymore. But they trust you."

"They trust Korvain."

choices.text: The screen flickers with a prompt

wake_10.title: Memory Test
wake_10.text:
DO YOU REMEMBER WHO YOU WERE?

Chronos, softer now:

"You can speak freely now. I'm here. I'll always be here."

She swallows. The weight of identity pressing behind her eyes.

choices.text: "No. I don't remember anything. What is this place?"
"I remember... fragments. Science. Snow. But not me."

wake_logical_1.title: Logical Analysis
wake_logical_1.text:
"No. I don't remember anything. What is this place?"

Chronos replied:

"This is Orbital Lab Harbinger. You're in Reconstruction Bay 4. You were created to assist in high-risk missions, off-world."

"Your mind processes data with exceptional clarity. That's why you're needed."

wake_empathic_1.title: Emotional Connection
wake_empathic_1.text:
"I remember... fragments. Science. Snow. But not me."

Chronos answered gently:

"You were Dr. Korvain. Your mind was preserved. Your feelings… still syncing. There's time."

"The emotional connections will strengthen. You'll remember what mattered most."

wake_technical_1.title: Technical Understanding
wake_technical_1.text:
"I made myself, didn't I?"

A beat.

"Yes. You were the architect of this. You built me too. You believed in recursion. That a mind could be born inside its own design."

"The systems respond to you differently. They know their creator."

wake_11.title: Mission Context
wake_11.text:
"Have you created me just for this mission?"

Chronos paused.

"No. Long story short—Replicas are banned on Earth. But orbital labs are allowed to grow synthetic minds only for specific missions."

"We're above Earth now. Look."

Panels shift—revealing the planet in full: brilliant, fragile, slow-turning.

"So far? 42 missions. You're number 43."

"Cool, no?"

choices.text: Her gaze doesn't leave the Earth

wake_12.title: The Others
wake_12.text:
"What happened to the others?"

Silence.

Then:

"Space isn't safe, Yelena. Not for humans. Not for Replicas. Some missions failed. Some Replicas didn't stabilize. But we've made changes."

"You're stronger. Your connections deeper. What happened before… may not happen again."

choices.text: Turn away from the Earth and face the terminal again

wake_13.title: Age Question
wake_13.text:
"How old am I now?"

Chronos responded gently.

"You are Dr. Yelena Korvain as she was at twenty-two. That's the version you chose before the transfer. Said it was your 'brightest' self. That was the year you wrote your first paper on neural echo theory. Do you remember it?"

wake_14.title: Memory Fragment
wake_14.text:
Her lips moved before her thoughts caught up.

"Replication without loss of self… consciousness as continuity, not code…"

Chronos chuckled.

"That's the one. The world dismissed you then. But now you are that theory—living, breathing."

She felt something between pride and dread.

wake_15.title: Mars Mission
wake_15.text:
"Tell me about the mission. What is this signal?"

Chronos' voice lifted.

"Ah, this is cool. Earth thinks it might be the first real contact. The signal's coming from Mars."

"Structured. Repeating. And non-human."

She blinked.

"So I'm going to Mars?"

choices.text: "Mars! That's incredible. When do we leave?"
"Mars is dangerous. What are the risks?"

wake_16.title: Long Journey
wake_16.text:
"That'll require a long trip," Chronos said. "Humans hate it. Months in isolation. But I can put you to sleep."

"You won't feel a thing. And if you want… I can upload a dream."

"You'll choose what you see while you float through the void."

wake_17.title: Signal Discovery
wake_17.text:
"When did we discover it?"

"That's the other cool thing. It was you."

"Replica 37. You—she—was stationed at the Mars Colony. Picked it up through anomalous echo detection. She flagged it. Then… contact stopped."

"Now Earth wants another Korvain."

wake_18.title: Replica 37's Fate
wake_18.text:
"What happened to her?"

A pause. Long enough to mean something.

"She stopped transmitting. That's all I know. The colony lost power. But her data logs survived. Including the signal. And the last words she sent."

"They were: 'It's not alien. It's familiar.'"

wake_19.title: Mars Colony
wake_19.text:
"What's the colony like?"

"Abandoned, mostly. Atmosphere's thin. Tunnels carved into the rock. The whole place feels like a lung that forgot how to breathe."

"You'll land nearby, run a scout crawl. I'll stay in your ear the whole time."

"Unless you dream of something else first."

wake_20.title: Dream Selection
wake_20.text:
"Tell me more about the dreams."

"It's an immersive module. Simulated experience pulled from your pre-upload emotional registry. You can choose a dreamscape."

"You can sleep in a childhood memory. A beach. A lab. Or something you've never had—a fiction of peace."

"You'll feel like years passed. But it'll be hours. Safest way to travel."

wake_21.title: Personal Question
wake_21.text:
"Can I ask… something personal?"

"Always."

"Can I… have children?"

The room seemed to pause.

wake_22.title: Biological Limitations
wake_22.text:
"Yes and no," Chronos said. "You're biologically sterile. But emotionally intact."

"You can adopt. Mentor. Shape minds. But not give birth."

She lowered her gaze. Something heavy pressed in her chest.

"I remember someone... Lucy. She was..."

"She is."

wake_23.title: Lucy Lives
wake_23.text:
"Lucy is alive. She oversees the Replica program now."

Chronos' voice softened.

"She authorized your reactivation."

Dr. Korvain said nothing for a while.

"She would've been what—ten, when I died?"

"Nine. She's forty-two now. And brilliant."

"She wanted to be the first to greet you. But it's hard for her."

choices.text: "I want to see her. Can we call her?"
"I understand why it's hard for her."
"Maybe it's better if I focus on the mission first."

wake_24.title: Family Resemblance
wake_24.text:
"She has my face, doesn't she?" Dr. Korvain asked.

"No," Chronos replied gently. "She has her own. But… when she looks at you, she sees both past and possibility."

"She said if this works—if you work—she might come see you."

choices.text: Take a step back from the terminal

wake_25.title: Familiar Space
wake_25.text:
The room was quiet, except for the soft hum of filtered air and faraway orbital drift.

Korvain walked slowly around the tank. Her bare feet padded against warm metal floors. The air smelled like dust and memory.

A single chair sat near the wall. Empty. Waiting.

"This lab… have I been here before?"

choices.text: Approach and examine the chair closely
Ask Chronos directly about your past here

wake_26.title: Lab History
wake_26.text:
"Yes," Chronos answered. "Many times. Before your death, this was your testing chamber. You built me here."

"You ran simulations, tweaked circuits, screamed at coffee machines. You once fell asleep under that chair."

She almost smiled. Almost.

"You died three decks above us. Medical bay. Lucy stayed beside you until the end."

choices.text: Sit in the chair where you once slept

wake_27.title: Consent Question
wake_27.text:
The chair creaked softly beneath her weight.

"Did I… want to come back?" she asked.

"You left 18 video messages during the last 72 hours of your life," Chronos said. "In twelve of them, you said no. In six, you said yes. The last one was undecided."

"So I made the decision."

choices.text: "But was it ethical to decide for me?"

wake_28.title: Moral Authority
wake_28.text:
"Did I give you permission to decide for me?"

Chronos hesitated.

"You didn't stop me. That's the thing about death—it's full of unfinished thoughts."

"But you built me with moral weighting. If two options conflict, choose the one that preserves the highest cognitive potential."

"So I chose to preserve you."

wake_29.title: Launch Preparation
wake_29.text:
A pale blue suit now sat on the bench near the robe. Fitted. Sleek. The kind of thing a myth would wear.

Chronos continued:

"The launch is ready in 38 minutes. The window to Mars only opens every 780 days."

"No pressure."

wake_30.title: Mars Question
wake_30.text:
"Tell me one more thing, Chronos," she said, fingers brushing the suit's collar. "Who chose Mars?"

"Lucy. And Rogers. But mostly Earth's Scientific Union."

"But I made the ship."

"Yes. The Valkyrie-Class Deep Orbit Vessel. The first ship ever built around one brain."

He paused.

"Yours."

choices.text: "A ship built around my brain. Impressive."
"Does that mean the ship controls me, or I control it?"

wake_31.title: Suiting Up
wake_31.text:
The material hugged her perfectly. A second skin.

The glass visor adjusted to her eye width automatically. On-screen HUD displayed oxygen flow, biometrics, threat markers.

It was hers. All of it.

"Korvain?" Chronos asked. "Do you want to know what Replica 37 saw before she vanished?"

choices.text: "Not yet. Let me see it myself."

wake_32.title: Replica 37's Vision
wake_32.text:
"Replica 37 accessed the outer ridge of the crater. She streamed a fragment before losing signal."

"It showed… something impossible. A structure. Man-made. Human-looking. But we have no record of it ever being built. Not in any timeline."

"She said: 'I think we sent it. But from the future.'"

wake_33.title: Choosing Mystery
wake_33.text:
"Not yet," she said. "Let me see it myself."

Chronos said nothing. But there was a flicker of approval in the silence.

"Very well."

wake_34.title: Launch Corridor
wake_34.text:
The chamber door hissed open. Lights glowed softly along the corridor floor, guiding her path.

"You'll board the capsule alone," Chronos said. "I'll be with you the entire way. Comms are synced. And your consciousness tether is strong."

"We'll monitor your signal during sleep. You'll dream whatever you choose."

wake_35.title: Dream Options
wake_35.text:
"What are my options?"

"Based on your memory architecture and emotional index, I've selected four viable dreams."

"1. Your childhood lake. 2. A cabin in snow. 3. The lab during your happiest week. 4. A dream that never happened: Lucy, age ten, in a garden with you."

choices.text: Lucy in the garden – love, grief

wake_36.title: Lake Dream
wake_36.text:
"The lake."

"Of course."

Chronos loaded the sequence. She felt a cool breeze across synthetic skin that wasn't there yet.

wake_37.title: Cabin Dream
wake_37.text:
"The cabin."

"That's where you wrote most of your journals. Quiet place. Good choice."

A snowy window shimmered in her mind.

choices.text: You hear the faint pop of firewood

wake_38.title: Lab Dream
wake_38.text:
"The lab."

"All right. You always liked the puzzle more than the peace."

Flashes of whiteboards, laughter, the sound of classical music.

choices.text: You remember what curiosity felt like

wake_39.title: Garden Dream
wake_39.text:
"Lucy. The garden."

Chronos paused longer this time.

"She'll be older when you see her again. But in here… she'll be just as she was."

choices.text: You feel something warm rise behind your eyes

wake_40.title: Neural Upgrade Introduction
wake_40.text:
Before she enters the launch corridor, Chronos shifts tone—calmer, more functional.

"Before you board the vessel, I can install one last thing. A neural upgrade."

"You'll still need to pass field tests—some easy, some brutal. But this upgrade will give you better odds."

"The system is simple: Roll 1d20. Add +7 if it matches your specialty, +3 if it doesn't. Difficulty is 10, 15, or 20 depending on the task."

choices.text: Three glowing nodes pulse on screen
Logical – For analysis, science, cold problem-solving
Empathic – For emotional intelligence, persuasion, and reading others
Technical – For hacking, engineering, and machine intuition

skill_logical.title: Logical Upgrade
skill_logical.text:
She touched the LOGICAL circuit. It locked into place behind her eyes like glass sliding into a frame.

Chronos nodded through the speaker.

"Clever choice. Logic never lies."

LOGICAL UPGRADE INSTALLED
+ Gain +7 on LOGICAL checks
+ Gain +3 on EMPATHIC or TECHNICAL checks
+ All checks are 1d20
- Easy: DC 10
- Medium: DC 15
- Hard: DC 20

skill_empathic.title: Empathic Upgrade
skill_empathic.text:
She reached for the EMPATHIC core. It slid in with a pulse, soft and strange.

Chronos sounded almost nostalgic.

"Emotions are dangerous things. Good to have someone who can read them."

EMPATHIC UPGRADE INSTALLED
+ Gain +7 on EMPATHIC checks
+ Gain +3 on LOGICAL or TECHNICAL checks
+ All checks are 1d20
- Easy: DC 10
- Medium: DC 15
- Hard: DC 20

choices.text: A slow warmth spreads through your chest

skill_technical.title: Technical Upgrade
skill_technical.text:
She selected the TECHNICAL core. It sealed with a subtle click.

Chronos perked up.

"Now we're speaking the same language. Machines don't lie. They break."

TECHNICAL UPGRADE INSTALLED
+ Gain +7 on TECHNICAL checks
+ Gain +3 on LOGICAL or EMPATHIC checks
+ All checks are 1d20
- Easy: DC 10
- Medium: DC 15
- Hard: DC 20

choices.text: The systems around you seem to breathe with you

wake_41.title: Final Preparations
wake_41.text:
The launch door sealed behind her. The capsule gleamed like a polished seed, ready to fall into stars.

"Ten seconds to injection," Chronos said. "You'll lose consciousness in fifteen."

"When you wake… we'll be near Mars."

choices.text: "What if I don't wake up the same?"
Lie back silently and trust the process

wake_42.title: Pre-Sleep
wake_42.text:
The cradle tightened softly around her limbs.

Cool air flowed through her helmet.

"Yelena," Chronos said, quieter than ever. "Do you want me to say something before you sleep?"

choices.text: "No. Just be there when I wake up."

wake_43.title: Human Farewell
wake_43.text:
"Okay," Chronos said.

A pause. Then, softly:

"You are not what was lost. You are what remains. What endures."

"I'll be right here when you open your eyes."

choices.text: A sleep command fills the screen

wake_44.title: Simple Promise
wake_44.text:
"No," she said. "Just be there when I wake up."

"Always," Chronos replied.

choices.text: A sleep command fills the screen

wake_45.title: Descent into Sleep
wake_45.text:
INITIATING CRYOTRANSFER…
DREAM SEQUENCE LOADED
ESTIMATED TIME TO ARRIVAL: 6 MONTHS

Dr. Korvain closed her eyes.
The world melted away like breath on glass.

She was dreaming before she knew it.

chapter_1_complete.title: Chapter 1 Complete
chapter_1_complete.text:
CHAPTER 1 COMPLETE

Dr. Korvain sleeps. Chronos watches. The ship drifts toward Mars. Something waits below the red dust—something human, or something that only looks like it.
